rsbNotes.title: Ps 126:1
rsbNotes.text: 126:1 When the Lord restored the fortunes of Zion. The allusion is to the return from Babylonian exile in the sixth century b.c., when the captive people of Israel were permitted to return to their country (see books of Ezra, Nehemiah). Cyrus’s decision to allow the return was not the mere result of political policy, but of God’s intervention.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 126:4
rsbNotes.text:
126:4 Restore our fortunes. Restoration from captivity meant more than a physical return to the land. God’s covenantal presence was still needed.

like streams in the Negeb. The south of Israel is dry, and in a rainstorm the wadi (seasonal streambeds) become dangerous floods.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 126:5
rsbNotes.text: 126:5 shall reap with shouts of joy. God reverses the fortunes of His people. He overrules evil with good, suffering with blessing (Ps. 30:11, 12; John 16:20).
